âBeazley CJ seems to have completely overlooked the fact that, if you give advice on the state of the law, you normally pay some regard to cases that have been decided on that point of law. Therefore, it is barely surprising that the late Chief Justice of Australia Sir Garfield Barwick is a person whom the Labor Party continues to pursue with its unforgiving tribal hatred, but nonetheless he is one of the greatest lawyers that this country has ever produced, without any doubt, and I will back Barwick against Blackshield any day, even though I was at law school with Blackshield. On this particular occasion I will back Barwick against Blackshield. In fact, I will back Burmester against Blackshield on this occasion. The Acting Solicitor-General has given a very strong opinion. It is very clear on the case law and, therefore, we have no intention of playing the legal and political game of the Australian Labor Party. Let them go elsewhere for Labor justice. We will not support any such motion.

answer.para: Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

debateinfo.title: MEMBER FOR LEICHHARDT: COURT OF DISPUTED RETURNS

talk.start.para: âI wish to move that so much of standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition from moving the following motion forthwith: that the following question be referredâ
âMr Speakerâ
âYou don't know what it is yet.
âYes, he does.
âMembers on both sides of the House seem to be forgetting my earlier comments.
âMr Speaker, we will take the motion.
âThe Acting Leader of the House has offered to take the motion. Is the Leader of the Opposition therefore happy to seek toâ
âAbsolutely.
âOne moment. Is the Leader of the Opposition therefore happy to seek leave to enable it to be moved without the requirement for the suspension to occur?
âI seek leave, yes.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âI thank the House. I move:

speech.para: That the following question be referred to the Court of Disputed Returns for determination, pursuant to section 376 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 :
Whether the place of the honourable Member for Leichhardt (Mr Entsch) has become vacant pursuant to the provisions of section 44(v) of the Constitution.

They are, of course, three matters in dispute in this entire sorry saga as far as the member for Leichhardt is concerned. All three matters are serious enough to merit the consideration of this parliament, and all three of them have to be dealt with at question time and at all the other opportunities that arise for us, either by motion or directly by question. Those three elements are distinct in their different characteristics, and all of them ought to raise alarm in the mind of an honourable member of the public looking at the requirement for his or her representatives to be accountable.

These are the three things before us. The first is whether or not the member for Leichhardt has breached the code of conduct. The mere fact that there is breach of the code of conduct, of course, does not necessarily go to his fitness for holding a seat in parliament. What we have seen as far as that breach of the code of conduct is concerned is the excoriation of the Prime Minister's expediency in his absolute refusal to give any cre dence, any credibility, to his code of conduct at all. We saw in question time today his slipsliding around every single point that was made to him. Every time he was asked a specific question he erected a straw man and then addressed the straw manâevery single question he was asked. He evaded every single question yesterday. He has, fortunately for accountability in this place, set himself a number of trapsâa number of contradictionsâto which we will have opportunity to return at a later stage. That is one of the elements that this parliament has before it for consideration, and a sorry tale that element is indeed.

The second thing before us is the probity of the contract. We went to a consideration of that during question time today. What we discern from that is that the Minister for Defence does not know what he is talking about, and the propositions that he put before the parliament misled the parliament in a number of key areas as to whether or not the advice of relevant persons had been sought.

Indeed, we have a document that points out that the flight sergeant on whom he relies pointed out to his superiors that Boral had marched in to complain to him that they had not been properly consulted and not been given the same opportunity to tender for the work as that given to the particular company in question hereâCape York Concrete. To their mind, the opportunity presented to that company was not presented to a respectable operation like Boral. And, apparently, there is another aggrieved party, we discover from the documentation, identified as a suitable tenderer whose views were not sought, whose business opportunity was not sought, despite clear instructions in the guidance manual to delegates that anybody who has a capacity to put in a competitive bid ought to be given the opportunity to do so.

That, of course, leads us onto the circumstances of the third problem that we are considering here today, and that is whether or not the parliamentary secretary has a sufficient pecuniary interest in all of this to run foul of the legal requirements contained in section 44(v) of the Constitution. Those legal requirements state that:
Any person whoâ

(v) Has any direct or indirect pecuniary interest in any agreement with the Public Service of the Commonwealth otherwise than as a member and in common with the other members of an incorporated company consisting of more than twenty-five persons:
shall be incapable of being chosen or of sitting as a senator or a member of the House of Representatives.

The effect of section 45(i) of the Constitution is that if a senator or member of the House of Representatives becomes subject to a disability referred to in section 44(v) his place shall thereupon become vacant.

The question arises as to whether a direct contract with the Commonwealth from a company that consists of two personsâwell fewer than 25âa contract established directly with not an agency acting on behalf of the contract (in other words, in a subcontractual relationship) but a direct contractual relationship with a department puts one in a position of vulnerability. A commonsense interpretation of that particular clause would say precisely that.

These are the circumstances in which the member for Leichhardt finds himself. He has been tryingâand the Prime Minister has been aiding and abettingâevery twist to get himself off that particular hook in all the questions that have been answered, or attempted to be answered, by them in this place in the course of the last couple of days. We have heard from the Prime Minister that it was all right for him not to declare his relationship as the company secretary or his relationship as a director, that clearly he was just a sleeping person as far as those requirements were concerned, and merely establishing the relationship was sufficient. Then they go on to say that there was not a pecuniary interest because he did not receive a payment in relation to that.

I would have thought that commonsenseâand the Prime Minister, strangely enough, despite having dismissed this as a possibility yesterday acknowledged it in answer to the honourable member for Dobell as a probability todayâwould show that there is another form by which one might gain from a contractual arrangement, and that is if that increased the capital value of a company and a capital gain was made: a commonsense interpretation by the Prime Minister today, dismissed by the Prime Minister yesterday as a matter that ought to concern us about these matters.

I have an apology to deliver in this place. I actually slandered poor old Henry yesterday. I saidâby implication at leastâthat what poor old Henry Burmester had produced was a quick and dirty proposition and of course you would expect the Acting Solicitor-General just to dance out there for the characters who pay him, and I discovered I was wrong. He produced a quick response, but he did not produce a dirty one. As Laurie Oakes pointed out last night on Channel 9, anybody reading this particular document sees it replete with qualification. This is a Solicitor-General trying to twist out from under two sets of circumstances: (1) he is very unclear as to the actual pecuniary interest and vulnerability of the member as far as this is concerned and qualifies himself repeatedly with `the facts as stated to me' through this particular proposition; and (2) he qualifies himself to the nth degree as to whether or not Webster is truly relevant or whether or not in fact a reasonable person might arrive at a different interpretation than Barwick CJ.

Just in case we missed the point on that, he went into quite some detail in the course of his remarks as to the challenges that have been put down to that interpretation, the narrowness of that interpretation and the fact that other decisions, though not directly related to that clause, indicated that the High Court might well choose to take a different view if those matters were expressed to it. Indeed, he went on to note in section 10 on page 4 that the Webster judgment has been criticised for taking an unduly narrow view of the commercial relationship required. On page 5, section 11, he notes that Barwick has been criticised for taking a narrow view of the definition of pecuniary interest. On page 5, section 12, he qualifies clearance of Entsch's pecuniary interests with the words `if being a shareholder does not create an indirect interest in the agreement'. On page 6, section 13, he notes that the High Court in Sykes v. Cleary was not as willing to read section 44(v) as narrowly as did Barwick.

I have noted five separate occasions where the Burmester opinion makes mention of criticisms of Barwick's judgmentâremarkable frequency in a document with only 10 paragraphs of consideration of the legal issues. In other words, he covers himself in every second paragraph of his opinion. I have heard of two-handed lawyers, but that is a very two-handed judgment as far as these particular matters are concerned.

That brings me to the reason we have some confidence in moving this particular proposition, and that is the legal opinion available to us. It is a legal opinion provided by a lawyer of considerable distinctionâone of the up-and-coming members of the bar with a very good reputation on constitutional matters. The Prime Minister felt it was pretty easy to dismiss one or two others who have been seen as people with a very considerable capacity academically as far as constitutional law is concerned. None of them were the people advising us. One Stephen Gageler was the person providing that opinion, and he provides an opinion very carefully couched. I go first to the summary of his views:
I consider that:

. on the material with which I have been briefed it is unclear whether Mr Entsch would be found to have come under the disability referred to in section 44(v) of the Constitution if the approach in Barwick CJ in re Webster were adopted;
. there is a substantial prospect that the approach of Barwick CJ in re Webster would not be adopted if the matter were to come before the High Court; and
. on the better construction of section 44(v) Mr Entsch would be found to have come under the disability for which the section provides and his seat will have been vacated.

In the reasoning that he puts down for these particular propositions, there are one or two points that I want to go to. The first point is that Barwick arrived at a very narrow interpretation of this particular clause in relation to who held responsibility or who was likely to be placing pressure on a member of parliament. While it had some legal precedence, it was not in fact the way in which it was commonly regarded at the point of time the Constitution was formed. It went to the argument that the only question at issue was whether the executive could utilise, via a contractual arrangement, a capacity to pressure a member of parliament.

One can think of pecuniary interest in far broader terms than that and, indeed, as was pointed out in this opinion, that is precisely what occurred at the Constitutional Convention. A far broader look was taken at the issue of pecuniary interest. It was seen more in terms of local government situationsâas a result of their direct experiences at the timeâand of course, in those local government situations, their concern was people making contracts associated with their local authority or arriving at decisions associated with land zonings and the like which would place them in a conflict of interest. Indeed, at the Constitutional Convention that was the issue being looked at most intensely. That broader interpretation might well be the view that comes to be looked at in this particular instance.

But even so, there are other areasâapart from the breadth or otherwise of the interpretation of what pecuniary interests meansâthat this legal opinion goes to. That was whether the very narrow interpretation placed upon the particular commercial transactions associated with Webster would be the circumstances that would govern an interpretation of the affairs of the member for Leichhardt. In effectâto put it in layman's terms, which are the terms I must put it inâChief Justice Barwick, sitting solely on this particular case, effectively placed Webster in the context of a hardware shop owner. Basically, all that was being transacted here was an application for a particular set of logs or pieces of woodâas you would go into a hardware store and say, `I want 10 of them,' and walk out. Therefore, the duration of the transaction did not involve an ongoing relationship, but was such that it could be describedâas it was described at the timeâas casual or transient.

But is this the case here, in the circumstances in which Mr Entsch's company finds itself? The answer is no. It is not simply a contract related to the bits and pieces that one might purchase to make up concrete. It is a transaction that took place, or required actions, over a period of at least a monthâor at least that is what we have been able to get out of the defence department, so far. Those transactions involved a service as well as a product, namely the mixing of the concrete. This creates a very substantial difference in the position related to Mr Entsch and the position related to the circumstances in which Barwick chose to find Webster. Since then, there has been an absolute load of opinion on thisâand it is bipartisan opinion, I should point out. For example, the Senate Select Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs in 1981, in its report entitled The constitutional qualifications of members of parliament, challenged that narrow interpretation that I referred to earlier. As the legal opinion says to us:

The thrust of that criticism was that the construction was contrary to the intention of the framers of the section as expressed in the Convention Debates and was contrary to the language of the section.
He goes on to find other interesting cases and points out, for example, in the case of Sykes v. Cleary:

. . . a majority of the High Court held that a person employed as a teacher in a State teaching service and who was at the relevant time on leave without pay was incapable of being elected to the House of Representatives because he held an `office of profit under the Crown' within the meaning of section 44(iii).

That is a much broader interpretation of that particular section, and if the High Court were to follow its reasoning in this particular instance it might well produce a very different decision about the circumstances of the member for Leichhardt. This individual was not receiving an immediate pecuniary interest, which was part of the fig leaf defence for the member for Leichhardtâa defence we do not accept, of course. As you will recollect, I referred to the possibility of a capital gain but, assuming that there was not the possibility of a capital gain and he was not receiving directors fees or any other form of remuneration from the company, we should recall the circumstances in which Mr Cleary found himself in this place. As many of us remember, the mere fact he stayed on the rolls as a teacher, though not practising and receiving no remuneration, was sufficient to see his situation discarded. Of course, we also haveâand this legal opinion refers to thisâa number of other cases which bear very directly on those conclusions.
Finally, I quote the opinion of the barrister who has advised us and that led to the conclusions that I indicated at the outset. He said:

In the result, there is in my opinion a substantial prospect that the High Court would, if it were called upon to consider the matter, depart from the construction of section 44(v) adopted by Barwick CJ in In Re Webster in favour of a construction which:

. treats the word "agreement" as encompassing any contract whether executory or executed within a short period of time and whether or not it is capable of leading to executive influence over a member of Parliament;

. treats a senator or member of Parliament as having a "direct or indirect pecuniary interest" in an agreement where the senator or member has a real (as distinct from remote) expectation of making some monetary gain or avoiding some monetary loss as a result of the performance or non-performance of the agreement; and
. includes within the expression "direct or indirect pecuniary interest" the interest of a shareholder as shareholder.

I think that, as you read through those opinions and you read through Henry Burmester's escape clauses, what you see would be a common judgment amongst the legal profession todayâthat is, the member for Leichhardt is in deep shtook. To put it in layman's terms, the member for Leichhardt finds himself in a set of circumstances which are severely problematic for him.

It is the duty of those on both sides of the House in this place when somebody finds themselves in that situation to find it and clarify it. Even as robust a character as Reg Withers could find it that way as far as Webster was concerned when it was last raised in this place with this level of seriousness. But, as standards have declined so much since then, so standards decline now and the government refuses consideration of this sensitive matter. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI second the motion and reserve my right to speak.
âI move:

speech.para: That all words after `that' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

The House determines that the member for Leichhardt does not have any direct or indirect pecuniary interest with the Public Service of the Commonwealth within the meaning of section 44(v) of the Constitution by reason of any contract entered into by Cape York Concrete Pty Ltd since 3 October 1998, and the member for Leichhardtâ
Mr Kerr interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThe member for Denison will resume his seat!
âIt is a disgrace, Mr Speaker.
âThe member for Denison is warned.
âMr Speaker, I will start again. I move:

speech.para: That all words after `that' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

The House determines that the member for Leichhardt does not have any direct or indirect pecuniary interest with the Public Service of the Commonwealth within the meaning of section 44(v) of the Constitution by reason of any contract entered into by Cape York Concrete Pty Ltd since 3 October 1998, and the member for Leichhardt is therefore not incapable of sitting as a member of this House.
In the light of all the hysteria that seems to be emanating from the other side, I would like to put this issue into perspective. Section 44(v) of the Constitution provides:
Any person whoâ

(v) Has any direct or indirect pecuniary interest in any agreement with the Public Service of the Commonwealth otherwise than as a member and in common with the other members of an incorporated company consisting of more than twenty-five persons:
shall be incapable of being chosen or of sitting as a senator or a member of the House of Representatives.

As is evident from the public debate on this issue and the debate in this House, there is not very much learning on this from courts. In fact, there is only one recent Australian case relating to the Constitution itself, which is the case of Webster. It was decided by Sir Garfield Barwick, sitting as the Court of Disputed Returns, in 1975. The effect of what Sir Garfield decided is that the words of paragraph (v) cannot be read literally. That is a view with which the Leader of the Opposition does not agree. The Leader of the Opposition is reported, in the Australian of 9 June, as saying:
The Constitution clearly requires any member of parliament not to have a pecuniary interest in direct links with the Commonwealth. These are direct dealings.

If one contemplates that for a minute, one can see what nonsense it is. If one buys a stamp, one has a direct dealing with the Commonwealth. If one buys a ticket on a Commonwealth train, one has a direct dealing with the Commonwealth.
Mr Adams interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThe member for Lyons! The Leader of the Opposition was heard in relative silence, and we will extend the same courtesy to the Attorney-General.
âThe member for Watson is warned!

âIn view of the effect of the literal interpretation there has to be a reading down of the provision, and that is exactly what Sir Garfield Barwick did in his judgment. He held that it cannot cover any agreement between a member or senator or a company of which they are a shareholder and the Commonwealth or the Public Service of the Commonwealth; it must mean something less than that.

speech.para: What he decided was that, to be an agreement within paragraph (v) it must be one which has currency for a substantial period of time, and must be one under which the Crown could conceivably influence the contractor in relation to parliamentary affairs by the very existence of the agreement. He went on:
. . . or by something done or refrained from being done in relation to the contract or to its subject matter, whether or not that act or omission is within the terms of the contract.

He also decided that the interests must be pecuniary in the sense that, through the possibility of financial gain by the existence or performance of the agreement, the person who is said to be disqualified could conceivably be influenced by the Crown in relation to parliamentary affairs. As the Leader of the Opposition mentioned, the original purpose of the progenitors of this particular provision was exactly that. The provision has its first origin in 1696. It has its more immediate origin in a provision in English legislation in 1782. It was, as the Leader of the Opposition asserted, debated at the convention debates and, obviously, they were relying upon the English precedent in order to formulate the constitutional provision. And it is to the cases on the English provisions that Sir Garfield Barwick has gone to derive the interpretation that he has relied upon. In no sense has anything that the Leader of the Opposition said denied the original rationale for the provision. The original rationale was to prevent the executive having influence in parliamentary affairs.

The opinion of the Acting Solicitor-General has been criticised. It has been criticised on the basis that there are inbuilt qualifications in it. I am unable to see any qualification in it, although at the end he does say that he relies expressly on the Webster caseâand if, like the Leader of the Opposition, you do not want to accept the Webster case, then obviously you have an immediate point of criticism. There has been some consideration of the Webster case in the 1981 joint committee report and there was some criticism of the interpretation put on it by Sir Garfield Barwick. But, in order to criticise effectively, one has to point to the respects in which Sir Garfield Barwick was wrong and, in order to be effective in the criticism, one must be able to point to an alternative interpretation and one must be able to say what there is other than the literal interpretation.

There is further writing on this subject. Interestingly, it was a paper written prior to the hearing of the case in re Webster. Interestingly, it was published after the decision in re Webster was given but it does not make mention of it. In it the author says, speaking at 1975:

At first sight s. 44 (v) seems extremely far-reaching, capableâif read strictly literallyâof disqualifying members for engaging in quite trivial or everyday transactions with government depart ments. The examples are familiarâbuying stamps, renting a telephone, subscribing to a Commonwealth loan, settling a compensation claim, leasing small plots of Crown land or residential premises and so on.

The author says that the provision has never been subjected to any direct judicial interpretation. That is now no longer correct. The writer's view is that section 44(v) is `capable of relatively precise, narrow and acceptable application'. Now there is a positive suggestion. Let me then turn to what the writer suggests the limitations could be. Having analysed the provisions, the writer goes on to say:

The preceding paragraphs have listed six ways in which, to a greater or lesser extent, the courts might reasonably be expected to limit the scope of agreements caught by s. 44 (v); namely, there must be an agreement, the agreement must have been entered into directly with the member or potential member in question, the agreement must be executory, the member must have some knowledge of its terms, the transaction must have been more than simply casual or transient, and it must be of public service character.

They are six qualifications asserted by this writer as relevant to a proper interpretation of section 44(v). If one takes each of those in turn and looks at the circumstances of the member for Leichhardt in relation to the contract between Cape York Concrete Pty Ltd and the Department of Defence, we can see that some are satisfied and others are definitely not.

First, there must have been an agreementâwell, there was an agreement relating to the provision of concrete. The agreement must have been entered into directly with the member or potential member in questionâthat is doubtful; it is certainly not the opinion of the Acting Solicitor-General. The agreement must be executoryâthe agreement was not executory when the member for Leichhardt first found out about it. The member must have some knowledge of its termsâthat was not true; the member did not know anything about it at the time it was entered into. The transaction must have been more than simply casual or transientâthat was not true; it was just a short-term contract for the provision of concrete. It must have been of a public service characterâI accept that one is satisfied. So, on several bases, the contract does not satisfy the requirements suggested by the writer.

I have been referring to `the writer' without mentioning the name of the writer. The name of the writer is the same as the name of the person who, on a bipartisan basis, is being nominated by the government as the Director-General of UNESCO. It was written by a Senior Lecturer in Law at the University of Melbourne by the name of Mr Gareth Evans.

talk.start.para: âOh!

âLet me remind you of what he said. It is the writer's view that section 44(v) is `capable of relatively precise, narrow and acceptable application.' He did point out that the original rationale for disqualifying government contractors was the need to limit the influence of the executive over parliament. But the second factor that he suggested that might be relevant in a consideration of the proper interpretation was that there could be a concern primarily with members using their position to their personal profit or advantage. In the circumstances where the member knows nothing about the contract being entered into, it is hardly a situation where the second rationale suggested by the member for Holt could be applicable.

speech.para: The Leader of the Opposition suggested in his address yesterday that he had slandered the acting Solicitor-General. In my respectful view, that is literally true. I have seen an AAP item, which I assume was the result of a doorstop or something similar outside parliament, in which the Leader of the Opposition asserts in respect of Mr Burmester:
I suggest he has a client and the client clearly has a preference for a particular course of action.
He goes on to say:
I think always a Solicitor-General tries to give advice that is of comfort to the government.

If the Leader of the Opposition had said that of a lawyer in private practiceâand there is more of what he said in the AAP wireâhe would undoubtedly have been very promptly in receipt of a writ for defamation. It is not appropriate that, just because a lawyer is offering advice to government and happens to be in the Public Service, that person be subjected to slander of that sort. Mr Burmester QC is a person of high integrity and high legal skills and he has, as the Prime Minister said yesterday, served successive governments of different colours with great distinction. To shoot the messenger in that manner is a despicable act by the Leader of the Opposition. He should apologise.

The circumstances in which the member for Leichhardt has found himself do not involve any suggestion of impropriety. There is no suggestion that he was in any way concerned in the entry into the contract. There is no suggestion that he had any role in relation to it at all. He is merely a part shareholder in a company that did enter into a contract without his knowledge. It was let in circumstances under which the defence department procedures were precisely followed. In the circumstances all the invective that is being thrown at him is totally inappropriate, wrong and should stop. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Having heard the Attorney-General and having given him the benefit of presenting his argument, I must ask you for a formal ruling that the amendment moved by the Attorney-General is indeed out of order. It is out of order because it is unconstitutional. It is asking the House of Representatives to act as a judicial body by making a finding of fact and a finding of lawâcomplex questions of law.

speech.para: As the Speaker would be aware, our Constitution specifies in chapter I the powers of the parliament.
Government member interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThere has just been a comment by some learned speaker that his constituents may want to see that chapter I of the Constitution does not specify the powers of the parliament. I can assure the member that, if he would like to get a copy from the Table Office, it will show precisely that.

speech.para: Chapter II sets out the powers of the executive. Chapter III sets out the powers of the judiciary. Of course, those powers are separated on the basis of the doctrine of separation of powers, which is the heart of our Westminster system. It is the heart of a system that thousands of men and women have died face down in the mud to defendâand here is the primary law officer of this nation wanting to fundamentally breach our Constitution in its most significant and most important respect.

It is quite clearly unconstitutional. Moreover, even if that point is wrong, the legislation of this House clearly prescribes a means whereby this issue can be disposed of. In particular, section 376 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act provides one means whereby it can be determined, and that is by way of the House referring it. The other action is by way of an individual application under the Common Informers (Parliamentary Disqualifications) Act 1975. But the only way that this House can become involved in the issue is through the operation of law as prescribed by section 376 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918. The parliament has no power to act in any way, shape or form as a court of law in a fundamental respect construing, in particular, another section of the Constitution. In that respect I must formally ask for a ruling on that point of order.

talk.start.para: âMr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. It is true, as the member for Barton says, that under section 376 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 a House in which a question arises, in this case the House of Representatives, could refer a question to the Court of Disputed Returns, which is the High Court. This is in fact the procedure that was followed in the Webster case. However, if one analyses the Electoral Act there is no suggestion within it that this House has prevented itself from utilising the procedure set out in section 47 of the Constitution, which provides:

interjection.para: Until the Parliament otherwise provides, any question respecting the qualification of a senator or of a member of the House of Representatives, or respecting a vacancy in either House of the Parliament, and any question of a disputed election to either House, shall be determined by the House in which the question arises.

talk.start.para: âI have no choice but to warn the member for Banks.
âBy providing one procedure there is no exclusion of another. That is the simple point in this case.

âOn the point of order, Mr Speaker, the Attorney seeks to conflate two things. It is perfectly plain that this House has given, through the Commonwealth Electoral Act, an exclusive jurisdiction to the High Court to determine these matters. This House cannot determine the matter that the Attorney has sought to place before it, to exclude the capacity of the High Court to resolve judicially a matter that can be properly brought before it through procedures like the common informers procedure and other procedures. It is an abuse of the procedures of this House, and you should rule accordingly.
âOn the point of order, Mr Speaker, the Attorney-General has quoted section 47 of the Constitution, and I repeat that to you. It says:

interjection.para: Until the Parliament otherwise provides, any question respecting the qualification of a senator or a member of the House of Representatives, or respecting a vacancy in either House of the Parliament, and any question of a disputed election to either House, shall be determined by the House in which the question arises.

The point I make to you, Mr Speaker, is that in that section of the Constitution it talks about `until the parliament otherwise provides'. We have provided. It is called the Commonwealth Electoral Act. That means that, since the enactment of that act and the other act that we are talking about, this parliament is now disqualified from determining on the qualification of its members.

The further point in relation to Webster's case is that the Attorney-General, or his representative, appeared in that case amicus curiae. In furtherance of my point of order, because the Attorney-General has moved this amendment, he now disqualifies himself or his representative from appearing in the High Court to assist the High Court. That is further evidence, I would put to you, Mr Speaker, because he is determining the question which will disqualify him or his representative from appearing in the High Court when this matter eventually goes to it. I say to you that this is a serious point, because the parliament has otherwise provided. It is the Electoral Act and the other matter raised in Mr Gageler's opinion, the Common Informers Act, that now disqualifies this parliament from determining on its members.

talk.start.para: âMr Speakerâ
âThe standing orders say that he can't speak twice to the same matter.
âHe can't speak twice to the same point of order.
âThere are some courtesies that really ought to be extended, and the first is the right of every member to determine first why he rises. I do not even know why the Attorney-General has risen.
âI rise on the point of order simply to respond briefly on the point made by the member for Banks.
âCan he speak twice?

âI just want to comment, without adding to what I said before, that the point made by the member for Banks relating to the Attorney-General appearing as an amicus curiae in the re Webster case has got nothing to do with this at all. It is entirely irrelevant to the point of order.

âThe question before the chair is for the chair to determine whether or not it is appropriate for this matter to proceed and whether it in any way impinges on the right of the Attorney-General, were he so to choose, to appear in any future case. There is no sense in which I as the Speaker ever make determinations that influence the outcome of constitutional decisions. This debate, it seems to me, is about whether or not the House is the master of its own destiny and as such has the right to proceed.

speech.para: The advice of Mr Gageler that has been discussed by the Leader of the Opposition clearly says that there is a substantial issue to be dealt with. Why should a lesser standard be provided to a person in a $175,000 business contract than a teacher on unpaid leave?

In his advice, Stephen Gageler has gone through the concept of pecuniary interest and he has gone through the constitutional debates. He notes that what was very much in the forefront of the minds of our constitutional founders was the definition of pecuniary interest that had grown up in local government cases. He said that the standard in those casesâand he refers to a number of cases sinceâwas that `pecuniary interest' has been determined as including a shareholding in a company that benefits from a contract with the local government. I ask: why should this House, the highest law making body in the land, apply lower standards to itself than local government? It should not. It should be applying the standards; it should be setting the standards.

There are very significant reasons. This is not academic. I do not have enough time available to go through the issues of our advice, but I will draw out the practicalities. We have seen the instance of Boral. Boral is clearly very concerned about the nature of this contract. Things not only must be done properly, but they must be seen to be done properly. Clearly, a significant companyâa company that has added considerably to the wealth of this nationâhas the perception, in a practical and a real sense, that things have not been done properly.

Where do you stop it? One commentator this morning said, `If you give them an Entsch, you give them a mile.' In reality, that is true. You are starting the escalation. The economies of South-East Asia have been devastated because of institutionalised corruption. On seeing these events, what will Boral and other companies say to themselves? They may well say, `If it's good for the goose, it's good for the gander. If we perceive that a member of parliament has influenced the Australian Public Service, we better start thinking about exerting our own influence.' If you allow this to happen, it is the thin end of the wedge.

Section 44(v) of the Constitution has a purpose. Its purpose is to avoid perceived conflicts of interest so the public can have complete and utter confidence in the administration of this parliament. They cannot have that confidence when members have the potential to receive pecuniary advantage, directly or indirectly, from contracts that their companies enter into with the Commonwealth. There are practical considerations. The practical considerations have been demonstrated by the facts. They have been demonstrated by the fact that a significant corporate body in this country has complained about what has happened. Around the nation, all the editorial commentâbar noneâis saying that the public does not like to see this sort of thing.

This debate is not about the Prime Minister's standards; it is about the Leader of the Opposition's hypocrisy. If members opposite want this matter to go to the High Court, they should pay for it, because the fact is that the taxpayers of Australia should not pay for what is nothing but a cheap political stunt. talk.start.para: âby leaveâI move:

speech.para: That this House:
(1) notes the detention in the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia of two Australian aid workers, Steve Pratt and Peter Wallace;
(2) notes that both aid workers were engaged in the provision of humanitarian assistance to the people of Yugoslavia;

(3) acknowledges the efforts of the Australian Government, the Government's special envoy, Rt. Hon. Malcolm Fraser, CARE Australia and a wide range of international leaders to secure the release of the aid workers; and
(4) urges the Government of the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia to release Steve Pratt and Peter Wallace forthwith.

I move this motion as an expression of the views of the House of Representatives and, more than that, as an expression of the views of the Australian people. There is no doubt that over the last few weeks, indeed months, the plight of Steve Pratt and Peter Wallace has become a matter of increasing concern to the Australian community.

I want to make two or three very brief points in support of this motion, which I know the opposition is going to support. The first is this: Steve Pratt and Peter Wallace are both aid workers. They are both humanitarian aid workers. They went to Yugoslavia in order to assist the people of that country, be they Kosovars or Serbs or people from any other ethnic group within Yugoslavia. They went with the best of humanitarian intentions and they ended up incarcerated in Yugoslavia. From our perspective, and I think the perspective of the parliament, we would like President Milosevic to treat Steve Pratt and Peter Wallace with the same humanity that Steve Pratt and Peter Wallace have shown towards the people of Serbia and the people of other parts of Yugoslavia. These people were not spies. These people were not engaged in espionage for foreign governments. These people were simply humanitarian aid workers.

The second point I would make is that Australia is not involved and has not been involved in the bombing of Yugoslavia. The NATO countries are engaged in the bombing of Yugoslavia. Yet I think it has been observed, and observed with concern, that three American soldiers were releasedâwe were pleased that they were releasedâbut our two aid workers were not released. The three American soldiers came from a country which is leading the bombing of Yugoslavia; our aid workers come from a country which is not bombing Yugoslavia. I think that point has been very much noted here in this country. We do not for a minute begrudge the release of the American soldiers, but we make the point, as a country which is a non-combatant in the war in Yugoslavia, that we want our people released.

Many Australians and others have made an enormous effort to try to achieve the release of Steve Pratt and Peter Wallace. Many members of this parliament have made a very good effort, as indeed have members of other parliaments. The Rt Hon. Malcolm Fraser, who has been the government's special envoy, has, as you would expect of Malcolm Fraser, worked tirelessly in this cause in order to secure the release of the two Australians. The officials at CARE Australia, Charles Tapp and others, have also worked tirelessly on this case.

As the Minister for Foreign Affairs, can I also say that we very much appreciate the enormous support we have received from leaders of international organisations and other governments. It is a long list and I will not be comprehensive, and I hope no-one will be offended if I have left them off the list, but I think specifically I should mention the efforts of Kofi Annan, the Secretary-General of United Nations, President Nelson Mandela, both the Greek and the Cypriot governments, a number of United Nations agencies, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights and others. Most recently President Ahtisaari of Finland, as the EU special negotiator on these matters, has been very active, as indeed has former Russian Prime Minister Chernomyrdin.

Let me say in conclusion that we are delighted to see a more peaceful environment descending upon Yugoslavia. We hope that now at long last the peace will be secured. But we do not want our two aid workers, at this moment of peace, to be forgotten. This morning the Prime Minister spoke to President Clinton and made that point to the President. I have written to Madeleine Albright and to Robin Cook, my counterparts in the United States and Britain, and I have had a very warm letter from Madeleine Albright and an assurance that they would not forget our aid workers. We as a government will continue to work tirelessly to secure the release of Steve Pratt and Peter Wallace. I know the parliament as a whole would want us to. I know other members of the parliament will do the same thing.

Before I finish, in the spirit of bipartisanship I mention that the idea for this motion came from the member for Chifley, who asked a question yesterday. I noted this and thought it was a great idea, so we have proceeded to do that. I would like to acknowledge the thoughts that came from the member for Chifley. We in this House of Representatives, we in the Australian parliament, we Australians want Steve Pratt and Peter Wallace released. This motion adds the great force of our democratic parliament to that campaign.
Debate interrupted; adjournment proposed and negatived.

talk.start.para: âI am pleased to have the opportunity to speak briefly to the motion moved by the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Today's news from Kosovo is more encouraging than it has been for some time. The Federal Republic of Yugoslavia and NATO have signed an agreement which provides for the withdrawal of Serbian troops from Kosovo. The Yugoslav foreign minister says that they will start pulling out later today. One Yugoslav officer attending the military talks on the Yugoslav-Macedonian border has been quoted by CNN this morning as saying, `The war is over.' Not quite yet, I think, but once there is confirmation that Serb forces have begun to withdraw, NATO will suspend its air offensive. The way will then be open to deploy the peacekeeping force, which should eventually allow the hundreds of thousands of Kosovar Albanian refugees to return to their homes and to rebuild their communities.

speech.para: Against this background of hope, today's motion records the grim reality that the two CARE Australia workers, Steve Pratt and Peter Wallace, continue to languish in a Yugoslav prison more than two months after they were seized. The fate of these two humanitarian workers, so unjustly taken as political hostages by a foreign government, is a matter of deep concern to all members of this parliamentâand, indeed, to the whole Australian community.

Today's motion is couched in very cautious and diplomatic language. It notes the detention of Steve Pratt and Peter Wallace. It notes that both aid workers were engaged in humanitarian work. It acknowledges the efforts made to secure the release of the two Australians. And it urges the government of the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia to release them forthwith.

Both the government and the opposition have used much stronger language in relation to this matter on previous occasions. The foreign minister said it was `incomprehensible' when Steve Pratt and Peter Wallace were convicted on charges relating to the collection and dissemination of secret information to foreign organisations and countries. The minister has repeatedly declared that Mr Pratt and Mr Wallace are completely innocent. It would not have been inappropriate, I think, for there to have been a more emphatic declaration in today's motion of our conviction that both men are completely innocent. Reference could also have been made to Branco Jelen, the Yugoslav CARE worker who has also been convicted and sentenced for alleged espionage. Though not an Australian citizen, he should not have been forgotten.

The words in today's motion are the government's, but the opposition does not propose to argue with them. From the very beginning of this matter, we have taken the view that there is no place for partisan politics when the welfare of two Australians is at stake. We have consistently given bipartisan support to the government on this difficult issue, including direct support by the Leader of the Opposition for the Prime Minister's representations to President Milosevic. In addition, the Leader of the Opposition wrote to British Prime Minister Blair urging him to ensure that the release of the three aid workers was not lost sight of in the broader efforts to secure peace in Kosovo.

This is not to say that we have not had some reservations about aspects of the government's handling of this matter, especially the degree to which the government differentiated the circumstances of Steve Pratt and Peter Wallace from those three American servicemen seized by the Yugoslav military. While it is true that the Americans were not charged with espionage, it is equally true that they were all political hostages. The Americans were released thanks to the efforts of the Reverend Jesse Jackson more than a month ago. The two Australians still languish in prison.

Serb forces are hopefully about to withdraw from Kosovo. NATO's bombing of Yugoslavia will hopefully soon stop. But the war will not be over for Steve Pratt and Peter Wallace until they are free and united with their families. The government has made much of Australia's support for NATO, but it has not secured the freedom of the Australian aid workers as part of the Kosovo cease-fire deal. Instead, Steve Pratt and Peter Wallace are still in prison, held as political bargaining chips for President Milosevic's Kosovo endgame.

There must be no let-up in Australia's efforts to secure the release of Steve Pratt and Peter Wallace. Today's motion is an appropriate part of this campaign. It should be forwarded without delay to Belgrade as a state ment of the determination of all sides of Australian politics not to let this matter drop until Steve Pratt and Peter Wallace are free and able to return to their families. The government must leave no stone unturned in Australia's efforts to secure the freedom of Pratt and Wallace. In that, they will continue to have wholehearted bipartisan support from Labor. I commend the motion to the House.

talk.start.para: âIt is day 71 of the detention of our Australian CARE workers Peter Wallace and Steve Pratt by Yugoslavian authorities. Their arrest was greeted with disbelief that two fine Australians could be caught as pawns in a European war so far from Australia. To be charitable to the Yugoslav authorities, it seems that this miscarriage of justice can only be the result of a misunderstanding of the duties and responsibilities of humanitarian aid workers.

speech.para: Peter Wallace's family lives in Mackay in my electorate of Dawson. Ross and Judy Wallace are widely respected and esteemed by all Mackay residents for their selfless devotion and service to the community. This esteem and regard extends to Peter Wallace, who is well-known for his humanitarian work. The courage and forbearance of Mr and Mrs Wallace during this long and distressing ordeal has been an inspiration to us all. Our local newspaper, the Daily Mercury, galvanised the feeling of outrage in our local community by organising firstly a petition and now a letter-writing campaign to the Yugoslav Ambassador to Australia.

The petition called for the release of Peter Wallace and his colleague and it was signed by over 6Â½ thousand people in Mackayâa heartening testimony to the respect so deservedly earned by the Wallace family. That petition was circulated to members and senators. To my parliamentary colleagues who signed it, I thank you most sincerely. Your thoughtfulness in signing the petition has given great heart to the Wallace family, and to the family of Mr Pratt as well. The petition was presented by Mr and Mrs Wallace and me to His Excellency the Yugoslav Ambassador. His Excellency received us most sympathetically and courteously. He was much distressed by the terrible events engulfing his country and, as a parent, he empathised with the anguish of the families of our aid workers.

I would like to take this opportunity to express our gratitude to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Downer. I know that the families of Peter Wallace and Steve Pratt, their friends and the residents of Mackay appreciate Mr Downer's calm, compassionate and commonsense approach to negotiating the freedom of our CARE workers. I would also like to thank the Prime Minister. Mr Howard met Mr and Mrs Wallace when they were down here some weeks ago. I know he has done his utmost to intervene to try to secure their freedom. I was particularly touched that, when he met Mr and Mrs Wallace, you could see that he was visibly moved by their quiet courage.

Deputy Prime Minister Tim Fischer also deserves our thanks for meeting and speaking with the Wallace family and assuring them that no effort would be spared to have Peter Wallace and Steve Pratt freed.

On behalf of the people of Mackay, I would also like to thank Mr Malcolm Fraser for his tireless efforts, as well as CARE Australia and so many others including Nelson Mandela, Kofi Annan, Mary Robinson, Jesse Jackson and thousands of Australians of goodwill who have sent messages of support. I know you will all share my sentiments and pray that soon they will be home.

talk.start.para: âMotions of this nature before the House require bipartisan support. The reason they do is that, when Australian governments and Australian non-government organisations send abroad voluntary workers to assist in the humanitarian disasters around this world, they are deserving of our support, irrespective of the difficulties in which they find themselves. The war in Kosovo has been an ugly conflict. We have all seen it on television; we have seen the enormous cost to human life which has already occurred. We in this country owe a great debt to aid workers of whatever nationality who put their lives at risk in order to assist those in need. Steve Pratt and Peter Wallace are two such individuals. We need to reflect on basic human qualities under these circumstances, qualities of human courage. When you are working in a war zone, and when you are dealing with the complexities and difficulties associated with conflict, it requires courage in order to do the task properly, and courage is something that has been in evidence in these two men's lives.

speech.para: When we look at the work done by international aid agencies around the world, including by CARE Australia, we as a nation owe such organisations a debt of gratitude. In areas where governments themselves cannot extend their reach in order to provide that assistance, non-government organisations such as CARE Australia are left to fill the breach. I take this opportunity to express on behalf of our side of this parliament our solidarity with the families who have gone through extraordinary anxiety during this period. It is difficult to imagine what it would be like to have loved ones who, already removed from us because of the work in which they are engaged in providing humanitarian assistance, find themselves in the circumstances in which Mr Pratt and Mr Wallace now find themselves.

As for the actions of the government of Slobodan Milosevic and the actions of the government of the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, our view is that these gentlemen have been engaged in humanitarian work and the accusations which have been made against them are unfounded. Therefore, we would call for the government of Yugoslavia to undertake appropriate action. The spirit of compromise and of resolution to this conflict is now in the air. We see movement at the United Nations. We see movement at NATO. We see movement in the various councils of Europe. It is time also to see movement in relation to the release of these two gentlemen. Their work has been entirely of a humanitarian nature, and it is time for the government in Serbia to release them and to release them back to their families.

On behalf of the opposition, I second and support the sentiments which have already been expressed by the shadow minister for foreign affairs in relation to this motion and would hope that the government in Belgrade will take early steps towards the release of Mr Pratt and Mr Wallace so they may be returned to their families and so that this difficult and sad saga may be put behind us.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: âI wish to make a personal explanation.
âDoes the member for Maribyrnong claim to have been misrepresented?
âIndeed.

âDuring earlier debate today, the Minister for Employment Services made the claim that I had not completely fulfilled my obligations with respect to the register of members' interests. As I understand the claim made by the minister, he was not querying the return that has been prepared for this parliamentâwhere it is as clear as day, even to the minister, that I have declared that I am a director of a company, Ronacar Pty Ltdâbut the return declared for the previous parliament.

speech.para: I have checked my records and the minister is wrong. talk.start.para: âWhen a serious matter involving the eligibility of Senator Webster was raised before the parliament, Senator Withers, leading for the then opposition in the Senate, indicated that the opposition would support a reference to the High Court, sitting as a Court of Disputed Returns, to determine that matter because it was of the utmost and paramount importance that such issues be resolved judicially and that to do otherwise would reflect discredit on the parliamentary system. That is not the manner in which the motion that has been proposed today by the Leader of the Opposition has been dealt with.

speech.para: Instead, the Attorney-General has moved a proposal to amend that motion, to determine in fact that the House finds that the member for Leichhardt does not have a direct pecuniary interest with the Public Service and is not ineligible to sit by virtue of section 44(v) of the Constitution. By doing so, he has elevated an issue affecting the interests of one member's eligibility, which was significant but appropriate for determination by a court, to a constitutional crisis.

More so, the Attorney has set this House on a constitutional conflict with the judicial system and has acted in a way that shows that he has no basic understanding of the separation of powers. A former Premier of Queensland, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, was reviled throughout Australia for not understanding that fundamental distinction. It is an extraordinary fact that the Attorney seems to be in a like position. He asserts that, despite the passage of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, this House has the power to clear any member of a constitutional act of omission or commission, and that that is a jurisdiction that exists alongside that which is given both by the Constitution and by the Electoral Act to the High Court of Australia. This is not an acceptable position.

The Attorney says that the Electoral Act still leaves space for this House to make such a determination. Of course it does not. It is a provision expressed until the parliament otherwise determines, and the parliament has otherwise determined clearly and explicitly by the Electoral Act. It is a like situation to that affecting the privileges of this House, where the Constitution provided that, until otherwise declared, they would be the same as for the House of Commons. When we passed the Parliamentary Privileges Act, those former privileges ceased to exist.

The real thrust and the real problem of what has happened today is that the Attorney, as first law officer of the Crown, will not facilitate this matter going before the High Court in order to have an honourable determination in a dispute where plainly there is divided legal opinion. Whatever else one says, the position of the member for Leichhardt's eligibility to this House is a matter of substantial contest. The Attorney will not facilitate that to be resolved in the forum where it is appropriate to be resolved, in the court. Indeed, what he seeks to do is immunise the member against the sins that are known to exist, and prevent any finding by the court to be made. I do not believe that to be constitutional but, more importantly, I do not believe it to be proper. The Attorney-General has disgraced his high office by acting in such a way.

This parliament has given up its powers to pass bills of attainder. It cannot make convictions. It cannot act in a way to convict a person. It cannot imprison them, save in accordance with the Parliamentary Privileges Act. It does not have the power either to excuse a person as a single individual from criminal liability or to convict an individual on criminal liability. The fact that a member's eligibility which is contested can be challenged by a proceeding known as a common informer's proceeding shows that at least it is a quasi-criminal jurisdiction that is being exercised. And the fact that penalties apply to members who sit in this House in breach of their constitutional obligations also shows that. For the Attorney to seek to have this House declare to exclude the jurisdiction of the court is, firstly, impermissible and, secondly, an abuse of the gravest order. This Attorney should be in shame for what he has done to disgrace this House, placing it in conflict with the courts and avoiding the principles of the separation of powers. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI want to place on record that, in a spirit of a certain level of cooperation, I allowed the member for Denison to participate in that debate. It is always difficult to say in adjournment whether one ought to intervene or not. It is fair to say that a question could have been posed as to whether the member was revisiting a debate on which the House has recently voted, and there is therefore a question of the propriety of what he did. In the spirit of the adjournment debate, I allowed him to continue but, having so done, I would not want to create a precedent. The member for Kalgoorlie has the call.

âThe war against drugs in Australia has never been so desperate. In the current debate on drug strategies a lot of the emphasis has been on new controversial programs to address youth drug abuse and I, like the Prime Minister, do not believe that so-called shooting galleries are the answer. They would send entirely the wrong message to the young people we want to discourage from the path of drug use.

speech.para: I wish to draw the House's attention to Teen Challenge. Teen Challenge is an organisation which started caring for troubled youth in New York City in 1958. The program now has over 300 autonomous locations in 50 countries, including at Esperance in my electorate. WA Teen Challenge's focus is on the whole person, not just addressing substance abuse. People resort to drugs because something is lacking in their lives. Often they come to Teen Challenge with a history of being unwanted, left out and forgotten. By filling this void with an emphasis on family relationships, work attitudes, self-image, peer pressure, temptation, community relationships and a variety of other life skills, Teen Challenge has an outstanding 86 per cent success rate.

As such, Teen Challenge is regarded as one of the most successful drug rehabilitation programs in the world, catering to single males and females between 16 and 35, mothers with children and families. WA Teen Challenge is a one-year residential program that has been helping young people in Western Australia since 1985. The program's centre in Esperance provides treatment for drug users through rehabilitation and offers academic programs focusing on character, integrity, spiritual growth and work ethic.

Experience reveals that it takes a full year to establish new lifestyle habits and patterns of thinking which enable individuals to live a drug-free life, helping them to become mentally stable, emotionally balanced, socially adjusted, physically well and spiritually alive, with TAFE courses also incorporated into the residential training program.

Teen Challenge's success rate is quite possibly the highest in the world at 86 per cent, and I believe the program's all encompassing approach to the wellbeing of the individual as a person, not just a drug addict, is the key to this success. Effective treatment, like that offered at WA Teen Challenge, is a genuine answer to the war against drugs, where the casualties are young lives. Yes, this is, indeed, a real war.

But only 20 per cent of hard-core addicts can get the treatment they need to fight their own addiction. A comprehensive study of drug treatment in California found that treatment is the most cost-effective form of drug control intervention. The study showed a real saving to taxpayers of $7 in crime and health costs for every dollar invested in drug treatment.

WA Teen Challenge offers both prevention and treatment to anyone in need as long as there is the availability of space. As always, prevention is preferable to treatment. WA Teen Challenge's Reaching for the S.T.A.R.S programâor students taking a right standâis a prevention teaching program specifically designed for Western Australian schools. S.T.A.R.S is a series of 40-minute innovative presentations developed for a high school environment to assist students to deal effectively with lifestyle issues, decision making, consequences of action and self-esteem. The aim is to encourage honest and thought-provoking consideration of themes such as running away, suicide, drugs, character and success.

Teen Challenge has also developed family enrichment seminars designed to give people enough quality information to be effective parents and family members. With 80 per cent of all people who come to Teen Challenge coming from broken homes, the aim is prevention. Life's Turning Points and Solutions are two more prevention programs. Life's Turning Points is formatted on small group dynamics, while Solutions is structured as a three-part seminar.

Currently, WA Teen Challenge is catering for 25 young people, with the expectation to grow to 35 in the coming weeks, and a waiting list for entry into the program of several months. Young Western Australians with drug and alcohol problems are in danger of becoming future statistics of drug related illness and death.

This program, led by Reverend Malcolm Smithâably assisted by Adam Davey, Peter Farrell, Stan Perron, Kari Rummukainen, Toby Carboni and David Newmanâis making a significant difference in the Esperance area. To continue Teen Challenge's outstanding work they need funding. I was greatly distressed to learn that Teen Challenge, despite the organisation's unprecedented success rate, failed to secure funding under the Tough on Drugs strategy. However, I am buoyed by the announcement in this year's federal budget that we can expect another round of funding in the foreseeable future. I have asked WA Teen Challenge to provide me with a submission, which I will be only too happy to promote to the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

talk.start.para: âI am mindful of your earlier ruling, Mr Speaker, but I do feel it is incumbent on me in the adjournment debate to raise some concerns that I have about procedures that took place in the House this evening. I would ask you, Mr Speaker, and I would ask the Attorney-General, in the non-sitting period, in the quiet cold two weeks that we have, to reflect on the decisions that have been made, to get a considered opinion in relation to this. It is my view that the House committed a grave error in relation to the amendmentânot in relation to defeating a motion that the opposition moved. It is my view that a considered reading of section 47 of the Constitutionâand considered advice takenâwould show that the House is precluded from determining in relation to individual members; that what we have done is give up that power to other acts of parliament: to the Commonwealth Electoral Act and to the Common Informers (Parliamentary Disqualification) Act of 1975.

speech.para: I am concerned not to take political points but that this House needs to set an example, that it needs to abide by the Constitution and that it needs to abide by valid acts of the Commonwealth parliament. The Attorney-General is the first law officer of the Crown. His oath is to act as a defender of the laws of the Commonwealth as first law officer of the Crown. He is not just another minister; he is not just another politician. I happen to like the Attorney-General on a personal level. I have served on a parliamentary committee with him. I do not say that what he did was deliberate. Today the proceedings happened very quickly. I know that there was a conversation with the Prime Minister and I know he was under great pressure in relation to tactics. But I say to you, Mr Speaker, that it is my considered view that we were in error today and we need to revisit itâoutside of politics because, if we were in error, if you find and if the Attorney-General finds on reflection that the House was wrong in passing that motion, we should reconsider it.

There is an alibi in terms of the heat of the moment, but there will be no alibi as two weeks pass, as a considered opinion is looked at, because advice will be sought. I know and I am mindful of the fact that you can go to any lawyer and you can achieve any advice. What we are talking about is forms and procedures of this House. One day the boot will be on the other foot. People are looking to us. The obligation of the Attorney-General is to sometimes take on his Prime Minister and the other ministers and say, `You can't do this. This is in breach of the Constitution. This is in breach of valid acts of the Commonwealth parliament.'

I say to you most sincerely, Mr Speaker, and to the Attorney-General that I believe a grave error was made today. It needs to be revisited. I supported the suggestion of the Leader of the Opposition that a period of reflection be allowed. Politics is one thing but, at the end of the day, we have to account. That is okayâthe government has the numbers and they could have voted against the motion that was moved by the opposition. It is the amendment and the voting on the amendment that concern me. I ask you to consider it and I say to the Attorney-General: `I think the House has been grievously misledânot deliberately but in the heat of the moment.'

We need to establish some precedents, because I think this House would be assisted by a determination of the High Court in this matter. I can rememberâand it was a challenge we did not take at the timeâthat the government did offer to fund a legal test case in relation to the native title case when we were arguing the constitutionality of that. But this is in relation to the qualifications of members of this House to sit here. The pecuniary interests register has a couple of things to it: not only is it there to show conflicts of interests; it is there to show real or perceived influence on members of parliament and real benefit if benefits accrue.

As far as I am concerned, Mr Entsch has real problems, and time will take care of those and they will be revealed, because an action before the High Court cannot be stopped. As Mr Gageler says in his opinion, another way of doing it is an action in the original jurisdiction of the High Court under the Common Informers (Parliamentary Disqualifications) Act of 1975.

It is not good enough for the government to have the numbers. There are some motions that come before this House that are above politics. If I am wrong in relation to the position I am putting to the House today, and if I take considered advice from counsel to that effect, I am happy to put my hand up and say so. I know there are better people than me. Mr Gageler, for instance, is well regarded at the bar. He has never been a member of any political party, and he has never been a member of Labor Lawyers. He gives his view honestly. I say to you, Mr Speaker, that I believe in my heart of hearts that that amendment and the advice that the Attorney gave today were wrong. If I am right, we need to reconsider it. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âAs the member for Banks understands, he was accommodated without the Speaker wanting to create a precedent but in the spirit in which he delivered that speech.
âI appreciate that, Mr Speaker. I thank you for that courtesy.

âToday I would like to draw the attention of the House to a community that, for most of the world, seems to consist of one person. This person regularly appears on the front pages of serious newspapers and magazines around the globe, although not so much lately. The various trials and tribulations of this community of one are often highlighted in the media and sometimes sensationalised for increased sales. Yet this one person community offers us a glimmer of hope. In the midst of grinding adversity, her community demonstrates balance, patience, compassion, strength of purpose and love. Aung San Suu Kyi alone is not the Burmese community, although from the Western media, you would be forgiven for thinking so. Although she has been off the front pages lately, let me assure you, Mr Speaker, that she and her community are still there, still focusing on their purpose and still paying the price. In fact, the price often rises as fame or newsworthiness fades for, out of the limelight, things can and do happen in the darkness.

speech.para: I am trying to make it clear that, although we are not hearing about it, the people of Burma, epitomised by Aung San Suu Kyi, are still suffering. As the human face of the Burmese struggle for recognition and political freedom, Aung San Suu Kyi becomes a target not only for our attention but for the attention of others less interested in her healthâand her health is suffering. After months of intense political and psychological pressure on top of very difficult personal circumstances, Aung San Suu Kyi's physical being has succumbed.

Again, we are tempted to offer to her the attention that we are not constantly offering to her peopleâpeople who, on a daily basis, self-select as targets for oppression by visiting her, listening to her, attending her meetings and being her friends. Not only do they risk themselves and their livelihoods but also those of their friends and families. This is normal life now in Burma, but we Westerners like to concentrate on the one face. We hold ego in terms of the self or the being above the actions. That is the reason we celebrate our birthdays, as if it is important how long we have been on this planet. In Burma, it is not how many years you have lasted but what you have done with your time that is important. Also important is the focus on the effort, not the person.

I ask you all here in this House and across Australia to make the effort to actively think about Burma and the positive options that you might have to offer. Keep Burma's people in your conscious minds and send them your thoughts. As a person of Karuna, or compassionate giving, I hope Aung San Suu Kyi will allow me to also wish her a happy birthday next week on Saturday 19 June, 1999âmy thoughts, and those of many of my constituents, are with you and your people, actively supporting and encouraging the lifetime of effort that you and they are expending.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

business.start.para: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER(Mr Nehl) took the chair at 9.55 a.m.

talk.start.para: âToday I would like to share with members the story of a young man that I have known for six years. His name is Troy Puttergill. He is a young man who was diagnosed as having autism at the age of four years. I met him six years ago. In actual fact, I helped him get his first job and he was very excited about that. It has been wonderful watching this young man develop.

speech.para: He is now 23 years old, and 12 months ago he took up swimming. He joined The Valentine Torpedoes Swimming Club in the Shortland electorate and he has shown quite a talent for swimming. This year, he went to the Australian National Titles where he performed very well, particularly in the 50 metres butterfly where he won a gold medal for intellectually disabled swimmers. He was selected in a special team to go to Germany and England. In Germany his performance was outstanding. He obtained a gold medal in the 50 metres freestyle, a bronze medal in the 100 metres freestyle, and he took one second off his personal best time. He received a silver medal in the 50 metres freestyle and a bronze medal in the 100 metres freestyle. He was part of a gold medal winning relay team in the 100 metres and they broke the world record. He was also part of a gold medal winning team in the medley relay.

Unfortunately, Troy became ill when he went to England and his performance there was nowhere near as good as his performance in Germany. The Australian team, though, won the Five Nations Award in England. He arrived home last Tuesday and I spoke to his mother this morning. She said, `He is still sleeping.' Troy is a young man who really shows what you can achieve if you put your mind to it. At four, as I said, he was diagnosed as having autism but he has never let this get on top of him. Troy's mother, Diane, has been behind him all the way. She has always put in the effort and fought to see that Troy got the best opportunities in life. He is a role model for other young men and women who have been diagnosed as having autism, showing just what you can achieve. Troy is a young man with a big future and I wish him all the best in that future. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe dairy industry is of enormous economic and social significance in this country. It is worth over $3 billion nationally. At the moment it is facing perhaps one of the biggest challenges in its history, which goes back some 150 years. What we have is a double deregulation issue, in a sense. There is a coincidence of the Domestic Market Support Scheme sunsetting and, at the same time, each of the dairying states considering their market milk arrangements.

speech.para: We now have a window of opportunity where we should be asking what other issues should be considered, other than a compensation package of $1.2 billion, should the industry become totally deregulated. We need to be asking: how can we ensure that this industry will be more competitive should a double deregulation occur? I think we should be looking at a number of issues, not just a compensation package alone. That includes, of course, how we are going to help the whole of our dairy industry to become more competitive. How is its R&D effort going to be improved? How are the skills in the industry going to be better than they are right now? That includes things like our apprenticeship systems; it is a fact that we have huge skill shortages across the industry.
