The fact is that more than 50 countries in the world have debts that will never be paid back but continue to be paid daily with people's lives. In Zambia every citizen now owes the country's creditors $790âmore than twice the average annual income.

speech.para: It is rather horrific to find out that in 1993 rich nations took back $3 in debt repayments for every $1 they gave in aid. We have this great feeling that we are doing worthwhile things when we give our money to the likes of World Vision and Community Aid Abroad, but when we find that, for every $1 that we send $3 is sent back to the Western world in debt repayment, we understand the problem that exists. Every year resources are being diverted away from the basic areas of health, education and sanitation towards unproductive debt service. Economic authorities around the world, including the IMF and the World Bank, have recognised these nations as technically bankrupt. If it were a normal commercial arrangement, debts would be written off, but instead we continue to saddle these countries with debt. It means that they are in a situation that they simply cannot get out of, and that they are worsening their own situation.

In 1997 the United Nations Development Program stated that 21 million children's lives could be saved if the money used for debt service was put into health and education. That is an outstanding figure, and it highlights the fact that we are not just talking about some economic factor; we are talking about people's lives. This is a one-off opportunity, at the start of the new millennium, to say, `Let's look at this problem in a serious way.' These countries are the highly indebted poor countries, the HIPC, that have no capacity to get out of this horrendous debt situation and are in a downward spiral. Meanwhile, the basic resources that they have to look after the welfare of the people in those countries, particularly with regard to health, are unable to be provided and children's lives are being lost, as well as those of adults.

The World Bank and the IMF established the HIPC Initiative in late 1996 to provide modest debt relief under stringent criteria to the worst affected nations. In setting up the HIPC Initiative, the IMF and World Bank accepted the reality that the world's poorest countries were basically bankrupt and could never repay their outstanding debts. The international financial community acknowledge that they need to take a new approach to this whole area.

There are four main areas where the HIPC falls short: the debt sustainability ratios are too high, there is a lack of flexibility for post-conflict countries, the means of determining eligibility for debt reduction are too narrow, and the time frame for debt reduction is far too long. What we are saying in terms of these initiatives is, `Let's take the opportunity; let's remove the debt; let's give these countries the opportunity for a fresh start.' We have the new millennium upon us, and Jubilee 2000 is all about recognising that by clearing the decks. It is more effective to undertake those programs than to give, on a continuing basis, the normal aid funding. Obviously we want that to continue as well, but this is an area that will be much more meaningful.

There is significant government involvement. The government of Tony Blair is giving significant support. In March, British Prime Minister Tony Blair welcomed Jubilee 2000 leaders to Downing Street and praised them for their great campaign. He agreed that the current form of the HIPC Initiative is not good enough. In a recent speech, Gordon Brown, the Treasurer of Britain, thanked Jubilee 2000 for `the sweep of your achievements so far, and yes, the scale of your ambitions we are summoned to meet'. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI would like to raise the issue today of illicit drug use. My electorate includes the suburbs of Footscray and Sunshine. Unfortunately those areas share, in common with some of the other suburbs in Melbourneâprobably five or six other hot spotsâthe infamy of being one of the main street trading and street using areas for heroin. It is a very confronting and unfortunate problem that we face in our community, but it is a problem which is suffered across the wider community. In areas like my electorate, where the street trade and street use is very heavy and apparent, it does cause great grief within our community.

speech.para: Several months ago the Labor Party federally released a drugs discussion paper which has been distributed very widely within my communityâto councils, to the Western Region Aids Prevention Service, to health and youth workers, to Open Family, to schools and to a large number of other organisations. We have received many responses dealing with the issue of drug use and some potential ways of solving this very difficult problem. I have been encouraging the community to be actively involved in this debate and will continue to do that while we grapple with the difficult issues that face us.

I also had the opportunity several weeks ago to have Labor's Caucus Committee on Government Service Delivery visit in my electorate the needle exchange centre that is not far from my office. It was very important for those Labor members who do not have an electorate similar to mine to be given the opportunity to look at the area, to talk with workers that are constantly involved with this issue and to see some of the devastation that is being caused by drug use in our community.

This is all part of a very important process that our community needs to own and be a part of. Since the release of the federal Labor Party's drugs discussion paper, the Carr government has held a very successful drugs summit in New South Wales which had wide-ranging representation from the community, from political leaders, from health workers, from community workers and from church organisations, all of whom had an opportunity to discuss the many and varied views that people in the community hold on this difficult issue. The summit resulted in 172 recommendations, which I think is an indication of how complex this problem is. The Carr government is now considering the appropriate approach it can take to this issue.

I congratulate the Carr government for its good work in this area and its recognition that such a complex problem requires a complex range of solutions, not just one single solution, to this difficulty. I would like to call on our Kennett government in Victoria to take the same approach. Mr Kennett has been very active in raising his concerns, particularly the increasing heroin use in our community, but unfortunately we need Mr Kennett to go beyond that. We need him to `walk the talk', not just `talk the talk', and along with a number of my colleagues I will be very active in trying to encourage the state government in Victoria to deal with this issue in a similarly balanced and open way. A large number of members within my community would certainly like to be actively involved in that debate.

We need to consider the range of solutions to this problem. We all know this includes education and prevention programs, but we also need to deal with harm minimisation for those people who are already addicted or who are in the unfortunate circumstances of not being able to get themselves out of their difficult circumstances and who see drug use as some way of solving the other social problems that they may be suffering. We need to look at appropriate detoxification. We need to look at whether or not adequate resources are being provided for the many health services that are needed to assist drug users going through rehabilitation programs as well as detoxification.

I also would urge the Kennett government to look closely at the issue of supervised injecting areas. I specifically call them `supervised' injecting areas; I think `safe' injecting rooms is a bit of a misnomer. We know that drug use is not safe, but we also know that harm minimisation is an issue which requires us to look a little bit beyond the norms, and maybe supervised injecting rooms will be helpful in saving some people's lives. It is an issue that I have an open mind about, and I think in Victoria we are not doing enough to look at the appropriate solutions.

I note that the member for Ballarat is going to be rising after me and I would encourage him not to raise the issue of Tony `Plugger' Lockett again today unless, of course, he is going to bring to the chamber's attention the team that he in fact supports.

talk.start.para: âWe are doing a tag team on this. I know the honourable member wants me to say some more about it, and I will. I was going to mention at the end of my five minutes today that on Monday or Tuesday when I mentioned Plugger's fantastic goal kicking record, I neglected to mention my cousin's wife, Di Nevett, who is Plugger's sister. I would like to congratulate Di. There would have been a significant family problem if I had not mentioned Di's name. Di is a pretty handy sportswoman herself and I know she would be very proud of her brother Tony and that magnificent feat last weekend.

speech.para: I was forced into that by the honourable member. I actually wanted to talk about something which is probably even more special than Tony `Plugger' Lockett's goal kicking record, and that is that a hundred very special people have moved from the school classes at Puckapunyal to school classes at Ballarat today. Robbie Cullenward, whose official title is marketing and media officer at the City of Ballarat, faxed me a press release last night to let me know that 100 Kosovar refugees are in Ballarat today. They will be having a fantastic time. A terrific program has been arranged. They were transported in buses to Ballarat this morning. They have been to see the Australian sheepdogs in action, and I am sure they will remember that. They are having lessons on Australiana and the 1850s gold rush. The program included an official welcome at 11 o'clock this morning by the mayor. The operators at the Australian Woolshed, which is a fantastic tourism venue, have rescheduled their famous ram parade, which has to be seen to be believed, so that these Kosovar refugees can see that in action. At this very minute they are at Sovereign Hill, no doubt Australia's premier tourism venue. They have enjoyed a typical Aussie barbecue. Some local school children welcomed them this morning with a very stirring rendition of Waltzing Matilda. Congratulations to the kids that were involved in that.

Sovereign Hill is providing an important element in the students' learning and understanding of Australian history and the story of gold in Australia. While at the tourist park the Kosovar children will try their luck panning for gold, catch a ride on the coach down the main street of Sovereign Hill, go underground on the mine tour and be treated to a special theatre presentation in Sovereign Hill's Victoria Theatre. This is a joint community effort between the City of Ballarat, tourist operators and the Ballarat business community. I congratulate everyone involved.

We as a communityâand indeed this parliamentâcan be proud of the way Australia has taken Operation Safe Haven as its own. Governments of all political persuasions can do so much. The fact that we have provided Australia as a safe haven is fantastic. As a nation we should be proud. What makes me really proudâand I am sure I speak for all membersâis the fact that so many communities across Australia have got behind this and are doing things like the City of Ballarat and the business community and the tourist operators are doing for these 100 young people. This is an experience for them. They are seeing something new. I think we are all playing our part to try and heal some of the wounds they have suffered. Operation Safe Haven can in no way heal all those wounds. That is going to take a very long time. It is a great tragedy that young children should have been subjected to the trauma that these young children have experienced. But I am proud that our great country is playing its part. The government contribution is very important, but even more important is the fact that the Australian community has got right behind this. Today is just an example of a number of things that have been happening all over Australia, through communities in the north, south, east and west getting behind this and doing something.

I welcome the appointment by Senator Kay Patterson of my colleague Fran Bailey as a Safe Haven patron at the Puckapunyal Safe Haven and my colleague Mr Lou Lieberman at the Bandiana Safe Haven. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: National People's Congress of China: 50th Anniversary

talk.start.para: âThis year marks the 50th anniversary of the National People's Congress of China. On this occasion an invitation was extended to the Australia-China Parliamentary Friendship Group to visit China and meet with the national and provincial officials of the National People's Congress. In the light of world events during and since the visit, the delegation was able to gain valuable insights into developments in the world's most populous country. Ten members of the House took part in the delegation, led by the honourable member for Aston. The delegation visited Beijing and met with foreign ministry officials and members of the China-Australia Friendship Group of the National People's Congress.

speech.para: A highlight of the visit to Beijing was a frank but friendly meeting with China's Premier Zhu Rongji. The meeting took place the day before the Premier departed for his visit to the United States. The Premier was confident of a positive outcome from his talks in the US concerning China's entry into the World Trade Organisation and other issues. The Premier expressed confidence in continuing good relations between Australia and China. As the delegation was to visit Tibet, the issue of the future status of Tibet and the role of the Dalai Lama was raised by the delegation. Premier Zhu restated the position that Tibet was part of China and pointed to the level of aid provided to the Tibet Autonomous Region by the central government. The Premier disputed statements by the Dalai Lama, suggesting that the Dalai Lama was free to return to Tibet as a religious leader but not as a leader of an independence movement.

Extensive discussions were held with the National People's Congress China-Australia Friendship Group on a broad range of issues including the progress being made with the reform of state owned enterprises, environmental issues, the status of Tibet and the Dalai Lama, the process of legislation in the National People's Congress, relations with Taiwan, developments in human rights in China and China's relationship with Australia. The group was particularly interested in the delegation's visit to Tibet, and again stressed China's position that Tibet is the inalienable territory of China and that the government of China is the legitimate government. With regard to reconciliation with the Dalai Lama, the delegation was told that this would require the Dalai Lama to give up any claims for independence for Tibet and to stop separatist activities. As for Tibetans living abroad, the delegation was told that they were free to enter and leave Tibet and that some 10,000 had done so in recent years, with 2,000 resettling in Tibet. En route to Tibet the delegation visited Chengdu, taking the opportunity to meet with representatives of their congress. Chengdu is pursuing the development of high technology industries. The province enjoys some advantages due to its more modern infrastructure and equipment.

Finally, the delegation visited Guangzou, where we met with representatives of the Guandong Provincial People's Congress as well as meeting with the Guandong Women's Federation. This meeting was of particular interest to the six women members of the 10-member delegation. The federation had received aid funding from AusAID for a project aimed at protecting the rights of women in the Pearl River Delta. It was interesting to note that issues such as domestic violence and the exploitation of women workers were being addressed by this worthwhile aid program.

I would like to thank Mr Graham Meehan and Mr Peter Noonan from the Australian Embassy in Beijing; our Ambassador to China, Mr Ric Smith; Mr You Wenze from the Chinese Embassy in Canberra, who accompanied the delegation; and the Chinese Ambassador to Australia, Mr Zhou, for arranging the delegation. I would also thank my fellow members on the delegation for making the visit an informative and pleasant experience.

talk.start.para: âI have risen in the Main Committee on a number of occasions before to speak of problems concerning Brisbane airport. Within its overall structure, Brisbane airport has a body called the Brisbane Airport Environment Committee. It is the principal body through which the community consults with the airport and relevant government instrumentalities on the management of environmental problems flowing from the airport, including issues such as aircraft noise. The environment committee was in fact established as a result of a recommendation of a 1991 report and has been in continuous existence since then.

speech.para: Since the privatisation of Brisbane airport in about 1996-97, together with other airports around the country, that committee has continued its functions. The practice of the committee, laid down for some time under different governments, has been that it has on it representatives from the affected federal members, state members and of the local councilâin the case of Brisbane, the Brisbane City Council. The federal member for Griffith, being one of the seats most affected by Brisbane airport, has in the past been represented by Mr Don Coulam. He was the representative appointed by my predecessor's predecessor, Mr Ben Humphreys, who I think would be known to some of the honourable members here today, fine member that he was.

talk.start.para: â A good friend.

âHe was a good friend of many of those present. My predecessor, Graham McDougall, also retained Mr Coulam's services. Mr Coulam has just indicated, however, that having been on the committee for some four years now, he wishes to retire. I have nominated as his replacement Ms Jackie Cann, who is the president of a local community organisation particularly concerned about aircraft noise as it affects the southern suburbs of Brisbane.

speech.para: I wrote to Brisbane airport and advised them of Ms Cann's nomination by me to fill this position. However, a letter received by Ms Cann on 2 June from the Brisbane Airport Corporation, copied to Minister John Andersonâa letter similar to the one I receivedâsaid that it was impossible to accept Ms Cann's nomination to the BAEC because such representatives are not nominated by the federal member but rather by the federal government. This is an interesting twist on developments as it flies in the face of the history of this committee going back some six years now. It also flies in the face of the minutes of that committee itself, on which the Brisbane Airport Corporation is represented, since the change of government in March 1996. In the minutes of a meeting of 28 August 1996 it is stated:

On the issue of method of appointment, it was concluded that the best equipped people to make the selection of community representatives were the local members of parliament/council, who after all, have been elected by their communities to represent them.

As a result, the [Brisbane Airport Consultative Committee] agreed that the current method of appointment, whilst not perfect, was still the best method available. It remains open for local members to appoint action group representatives if they believe they are the best people for the job.

This matter was further clarified in correspondence to the previous minister for transport, Mr Mark Vaile, by Mr Alexander Zeverijn, Chairman of the Brisbane Airport Environment Committee, who is also, I understand, an employee of the Brisbane Airport Corporation. In this letter of 16 February 1998, the chairman of the committee goes on to say that `the essential elements of the revised terms of reference' of the Brisbane Airport Environment Committee include, among others `that community members continue to be appointed by the local, state and federal members'. Based on these documents, I would say that there is somewhat incontrovertible proof that the practice adhered to since 1991 has in fact been ratified under the current government as well.

I find it therefore passing strange that the Brisbane Airport Corporation could take exception to the current member for Griffithânamely, myselfâmaking a new nomination to that committee. I can only conclude that the Brisbane Airport Corporation has not found me to be their favourite pin-up boy for the simple reason that I have given them such a hard time on their management of environmental questions and aircraft noise, particularly in the southern suburbs of Brisbane.

I have therefore written to the current minister for transport, Minister Anderson, seeking his support to simply continue the practice in this area which has occurred under previous members, Labor and Liberal, since 1991.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 12 May 1999:

question.para: (1) Under the Regional Assistance Program (RAP), what is the status of the memorandum of understanding between the departments governing the operation of area consultative committees.

(2) What is the nature of the (a) planning and funding process, (b) performance assessment and project evaluation tools, (c) simplified RAP guidelines and (d) updated Internet and email facilities relating to the operation of area consultative committees.
(3) Will Ministers and Members play a greater role in the announcement of projects funded under the RAP; if so, how.
(4) Have guidelines been established for area consultative committees to determine which Members will be consulted and involved in the preparation and announcement of projects funded under the RAP.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) was signed on 30 March by the Ministers for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business; Education, Training and Youth Affairs and Transport and Regional Services. It came into operation on that date. A copy of the MOU is attached.

(2) (a) Area Consultative Committees (ACCs) are required to develop a three year Strategic Regional Plan and an annual Business Plan. The Strategic Plan outlines the ACC's broad strategy for employment and regional growth and skills development in its particular region. ACCs are encouraged to develop Strategic Plans which provide an analysis of the issues and problems affecting the region, an indication of priorities for the region, a statement of the outcomes the ACC expects to achieve and an indication of the strategies the ACC will follow to achieve these outcomes. The Annual Business Plan is a practical document addressing costings of each ACC's operations and RAP activity for the year for budget administration purposes.
The Commonwealth provides funds to support the operation of ACCs. Base funding of $7m was allocated in 1998/99 for ACC operations.

Funds are allocated ($33.3m* for this financial year) to State level on the basis of State unemployment levels. Additional allocation is provided to Tasmania and the Northern Territory in recognition of the geographic isolation of their labour markets.
(*NB this amount includes funding for business incubators, national emergencies if required or nationally significant projects).

State level indicative funding allocations for ACCs are based on their annual Business Plans. In determining an indicative funding allocation, the department may consider such factors as each ACC region's:
- unemployment levels;
- share of population;
- forward project liability from previous financial years;
- previous level of RAP activity;
- share of youth and indigenous Australian populations;
- size of labour force.
Both operational and project funding arrangements are under review in consultation with ACC Chairs, with the aim of introducing improved, nationally consistent arrangements for next financial year.

(b) To date there has been no formal mechanism through which to assess the performance of an ACC or to evaluate the impact of RAP projects. The department has engaged a consultant to develop an assessment and evaluation tool in consultation with ACCs.
(c) A National Policy Framework and Guidelines for RAP are currently being developed in consultation with ACC Chairs and Executive Officers. A guide for applicants is being updated.

(d) There is a public web site for ACCs on the Internet. This site provides information on, and contact points for, each ACC. The department has recently instigated a project to update the site on a regular basis, eg remove out of date information, update and correct links to other sites and improve menu access. It is also proposed to establish a secure (private) ACC web site for the purpose of improving communication between the department and ACCs and between ACCs. As an interim measure an email list (or `acclist') has been established which allows secure communication between ACCs and ACCs and the department.
(3) All RAP projects will be referred to the Minister for Employment Services for announcement.
MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING
Between: Ministers for
. Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business
. Education, Training and Youth Affairs
. Transport and Regional Services
Purpose

The purpose of this Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) is to establish a cooperative working relationship between the Ministers' portfolio departments in relation to the utilisation of Area Consultative Committees (ACCs).
Background

ACCs bring together key industry, employer, and community representatives to identify priorities and opportunities for employment and economic development as well as linked education and training issues in their region. A network of 58 committees Australia-wide was established to provide regional leadership so regions could make the most of their economic and labour market strengths. The ACC Network is allocated operating funds through the Regional Assistance Program.

The Government considers the ACC Network an important element in the achievement of its goals for employment and economic growth in metropolitan, regional and rural Australia. It has a primary communication role within its local community to both promote and disseminate government programs and initiatives; and provide advice and feedback on the impact of those initiatives to better inform implementation of the employment services market reforms.

ACCs will continue to be administered by and operate under the Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. Through that department ACCs will have a strong relationship with the Departments of Education, Training and Youth Affairs and Transport and Regional Services. The Department of Transport and Regional Services has a primary role in coordinating programs and activities that affect rural and regional Australia across a range of portfolios.
Responsibilities

The proposed approach for this MOU will bring together the signatories, or their designated representatives, to provide leadership for effective communication, monitor and assess policy implementation issues, address data needs, improve overall management of dissemination and promotion of Government programs and initiatives through the ACC Network.

A coordinating group will be established to enable practical implementation of the principles underlying the MOU. The group will be chaired by Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business and comprise of representatives from the Departments of Transport and Regional Services and Education, Training and Youth Affairs.

. Consultation between the three portfolios, on the Regional Assistance Program, the strategic role, charter and operation of ACCs with a focus on identifying matters for inclusion in the annual statement of priorities issued by Ministers.
. The provision of advice and reports on relevant areas of interest to each portfolio will be forwarded to the designated representative.
. Access to ACCs, including national meetings/strategic planning sessions of ACC chairs and to appropriate ACCs on regional visits will be facilitated for each portfolio.
. The sharing of information on portfolio priorities that may affect ACCs will be undertaken regularly.
. The Ministers' offices will confer in advance of any major announcements impacting on regional Australia.
. ACC advice and feedback on impact of government programs and initiatives will be provided to the relevant portfolio through appropriate communication mediums.
. Each portfolio will give consideration of resource implications where a discrete activity is requested of the ACC Network.
. Through consultation, appropriate communication mechanisms will be determined, developed, maintained and, as appropriate, funded.
Authority
This MOU becomes effective upon its signature by relevant Ministers. The MOU will continue in effect for three years, be reviewed annually and be modified by mutual consent.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 May 1999:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 551 (Hansard , 12 May 1999, page 4343) about Holsworthy Correctional Centre, was the use of Defence Force Corrective Establishment standing orders as a means of indicating new punishments referred to in the Department of Defence's submission to the inquiry of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade into military justice procedures; if not, why not.
(2) What is the head of power in the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 that allows for the development of new punishments.
(3) Have the standing orders provided for new punishments.
(4) What is the specific standing order covering attitude adjustment training.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Veterans' Affairs; Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The use of the Defence Force Corrective Establishment standing orders as a means of indicating new punishments was not referred to in the Department of Defence's submission to the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Inquiry into Military Justice Procedures in the Australian Defence Force. Punishments that follow from the formal disciplinary process are prescribed in the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 and there is no other source or authority for the imposition of punishments. The Defence Force Corrective Establishment is a military establishment that has a role in the implementation of certain sentences awarded to Australian Defence Force members by Service Tribunals. The Defence Force Corrective Establishment standing orders are not a means of indicating new punishments and have no relevance to the formal disciplinary procedures of sentence established by the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982. As the Defence Force Corrective Establishment cannot in itself award sentences to Australian Defence Force members, its standing orders were not referred to in that context in the submission to the Inquiry.

(2) Only Service Tribunals under the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 may award disciplinary punishments as prescribed by the Act. There is no head of power that permits a Service Tribunal or a Defence entity, such as the Defence Force Corrective Establishment, to develop and impose new punishments. Development of new punishments requires legislative amendment.

(3) The Defence Force Corrective Establishment standing orders do not provide for new punishments, nor were they intended to provide for punishments in terms of the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982. The standing order provision for `Discipline Tours', which over time transformed into `Attitude Adjustment Training', was solely intended to familiarise selected Australian Defence Force members with the procedures involved in serving detention at the Defence Force Corrective Establishment should they later be awarded detention by a Service Tribunal in accordance with the provisions of the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982.

(4) The Defence Force Corrective Establishment standing orders of June 1996 at Annex B to Chapter 5 included a flow-chart relating to Discipline Tour procedures. In December 1996, the Defence Force Corrective Establishment was subsumed by the Military Police School. The Military Police School standing orders were amended to incorporate the operation of the Defence Force Corrective Establishment, and its standing orders included staff duty statements which detailed instructions for conducting Discipline Tours. Discipline Tours were suspended in July 1997 and all reference to Discipline Tours was deleted from subsequent standing orders. The practice of Discipline Tours or Attitude Adjustment training has not been undertaken since July 1997, nor is there any proposal to reintroduce the practice.
